title: Dynamique queue will NEVER be a true ladder experience
body:
It won't. It cannot be. You're shoving premades and solo players onto the same ladder, and by doing this you have made each player's elo WORTHLESS. A silver level player can EASILY get carried to diamond if he has 3-4 pals to carry him there. And if he plays games with his now-diamond mmr he will RUIN the game for 4 other people. If you don't think that's a problem, you (looking at you riot) are an idiot.

Each player's mmr no longer matters as of s6. There's too many variables now. You can't look at 2 player's mmr and justifiably say who is the better solo queue player. One could have higher mmr than the other just by getting carried by his friends. Dynamic queue therefore has made mmr meaningless. It means nothing.

How do we make dynamic queue a true ladder experience? Quite simply, you can't. By its very nature you're combining several different queues into one mmr. Which is unbelievably stupid. 'But now you can play ranked with your frandssss'. NO. THERE IS NO RANKED ANYMORE. IF THE LADDER IS MEANINGLESS, IT IS NOT RANKED.

So basically this is riot's logic: we want to allow you to play with your friends (something you could already do in normal games) but they wanted it to be ranked experience (which we also already had with teambuilder). But they wanted it to be easy for the player. You could queue as 1, 2, 3, 4, even 5 players all in the same ladder, all with the same mmr. Yea? Well, in doing so, ranked has been destroyed. Now there are just 2 versions of normal draft queue, one just happens to have meaningless divisions attached to with some meaningless rewards.

There is no ranked play anymore. You want a real, fair, meaningful competitive experience? Go play a different game.

The issue with premades is more with the blatant communication advantage. That's why the system is supposed to be prioritizing premades vs premades. In my experience from Draft normals, I am better playing solo than in a premade without chat. It's pretty much an unwritten rule that you are expected to use some voice chat if you are queuing up as a premade.

This is where some Solo players will get cheated. They will get thrown in with a four man premade that isn't using chat, which is basically the same as four solo players that just happen to know each other. Then you'll get pitted against a four or five man that is using chat. Playing field isn't equal.

This is mostly Riot's fault for not implementing a voice chat. I get the concerns of toxicity and verbal abuse, but how can you encourage a competitive queue that relies on third party software to create an equal playing field?

I agree with this argument. I think people aren't even considering the fact that old SoloQ was not that great. It was hardly a real ladder experience, especially if you were like me and played StarCraft2 for two years before even trying League of Legends. The key difference is that W/L is far more comprehensive in a 1v1 scenario than a 5v5 scenario where everyone sees themselves as Solo players. In SC2, you could look at your ladder for a general clue as to who you may end up facing in your MMR, but in LoL seeing the people around you in your division is completely pointless. 

For a true ladder experience to work in LoL, Riot would have to weaken the LP gain/loss from W/L and place greater importance on personal statistics in each game. While theoretically the stat spread to LP conversion could be a decent implementation, the fact that League is a total melting pot of variables that influence stats radically every game means this system would have to be revolutionary. Sure, I make an impact in games I win, but in the new system you'd be pitted against everyone else in those regards. People would complain the system is too harsh and judgmental, requiring too much dedication to proceed.

The thing is that, until Riot develops a system that judges you on your personal stats every game rather than basing most of your LP gain on whether you win or lose, League's Ranked will simply not be a true ladder system. 

I don't even know if a true Ladder system would work well in League. There is so much complexity involved with the game, with 10 players and all the statistical variables that need to be accounted for, so it's not remotely as simple as everyone demands. If it isn't implemented flawlessly, then we'll have literally the same upheaval we have now on the Boards.

Numerous Rioters have said that that sort of system will never happen. 

They don't want anything detrimental to happen to a player who picks support or jungle or a tanky top or lissandra and then makes the proper team move to engage a fight in which they will likely die which ruins their kda or damage dealt or gpm even though their team wins the fight and maybe the game.  If you got less LP because you picked rammus and went 1/7/17 in a win than you did for picking shaco and going 14/3/4 in a win but did gobs more damage, that just wouldn't be fair.

 People would never want to play certain champions because they would get less LP just by how the champion plays based on which stats rito is awarding LP for.

Not exactly. In SC2, you are judged on a _**1v1 W/L scenario**_ featuring only your MMR. As you win, your MMR improves and you are matched with this within your MMR at your Tier. You can literally look at the ladder to see who your likely opponents are going to be. In SC2, you are only responsible for yourself and your own strategies. The only other variable to take into account is your opponent. Now, you will still play people outside your Tier if you do well enough, but my point is that your W/L should typically be split 50/50 as you win because you will undoubtedly run into others with your MMR. SC2's ladder system isn't perfect, but because it only has to keep into account a 1v1 scenario, it's far more accurate as a ladder experience.

In League, you have a 5v5 W/L scenario that factors in your personal MMR, your ELO, and your Division. Unfortunately, looking at the ladder of your division is completely pointless; because of the many variables and high population, you'll rarely play the people in your own Division and you'll still end up matched against people in other Divisions/Tiers. That's not necessarily a problem, but it is NOT a true ladder experience as others demand for. Those same variables are applied to the other 9 people going into a game with you and W/L is determined based more on their performance than yours alone.

While I can't say for sure given I'm not a High ELO player, it seems that League's ladder system is more cohesive the higher up you go because the population decreases in each tier. That's probably an intended design because it's more reliable at higher ELO.

Not exactly, in starcraft 2 due to the small sample of player you are more likely to play against a player you are favored against or the contrary (when i was GM i could still play diamonds players sometime, and when you play at like 6/7 am you end up playing against plat players sometimes, but thats another problem). 

If you have a really large player base, as it is the case in LoL, you are pretty sure you are matched with and against people your own mmr. And that's the point : Division is really different than MMR. When i was on losing streak at plat 5 i ended up playing with full gold 3/4 players and against full gold 3/4 players, because that's where my mmr did belong. If you are on a winning streak (like 15 games in a row), your MMR grew faster than your LP, so you can play vs diamonds and still be gold I. I remember a guy who left all his BO to stay bronze 1 but still had a diamond ELO, so the system matched him with and against diamond even tough he was bronze.

(TL;DR : The divisions are just some shiny grades you show to your friends, they do not matter at all to determine against who and with who you will be matched, note that sc2 works exactly the same way, some of my GM friend are constantly leaving the challenger leagues on purpose with their ||||||||||||||| accounts to stay anonymous, so they ends up being plat most time, but they are matched against GM and people their own MMR).

That's a lot, and this explains alone the difference of performances of the players between all their games, plus the fact some match ups are favored in one or the other side.

130 champs
6 bans
it means that there are 124x123x122x121x120x119x118x117x116x115 combinations (5.9* 10^20)

While I'm not a fan of dynamic queue because it took team builder away from me, I have a fun challenge to the people in this thread that think dynamic queue's style of match making is something new to ranked play.

**Name 1 competitive esports game that has team-based ranked play where solo players and grouped players cannot intermingle.**

CS-GO, Halo, COD, Rainbow 6 Siege, Starcraft (has 2v2s, 3v3s IIRC), DOTA, etc. Every single one of these games has ranked play where solo players can be matched with groups. It is the industry _standard_ to do this type of matchmaking.
So when you say that this type of matchmaking makes individual elo worthless, you are flat out wrong. If you actually stop to consider the mountain of data on the subject it is clearly effective. It works across multiple games on multiple platforms. This method has always resulted in the best rising to the top.
So I ask you OP, what other game? Because there is no other game that doesn't use this same method.
